instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
Had liquid damage on <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>, which I replaced.

Could this be a faulty <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>?

It looks like an RTC reset that repeats ad nauseam.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
Do you get variations at pin1?
It must be always high.
Remove <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and clean all that area and its pads; then resolder it.
Pin12 has stable clock?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>::1 is going up and down.

I'll replace it and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message: Be sure first if <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is correctly powered up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
Just noticed that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is power cycling.
Didn't pick up on it the first time I looked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message: if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is power cycling something up the line is shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message: PPBUS even stable? <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing could also be <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing. <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> coming high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
PPBus is stable.

It seems to be boot every now and then, but mostly power cycles.
Will check <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> in a moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is stable.

Ugh, <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is cycling. But every five or ten powers I can get it stable, then it boots fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Does RTC reset over and over.
threads.message: SMC issue, probably crap under it.
